content: The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" is introduced, which excludes space-related income from gross income according to a new section 139B in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" introduces a new section 139B in the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, excluding space-related income from gross income. Space-related income includes income derived from products or services produced or provided in outer space. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts income from services performed in outer space in a trade or business. This includes interest, rent, royalty, or similar amounts related to production or services in outer space. Telecommunications services from earth orbit and services from weather or earth observation satellites are exceptions to this rule. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts income from services performed in outer space in a trade or business, including telecommunications services from earth orbit and services from weather or earth observation satellites. The act also excludes wages received by employees and specifies proportional allocation between space-based and earth-based activities for products produced partly in space. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" excludes income from services in outer space and wages of employees. It also specifies proportional allocation for products produced partly in space. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts space launch and manufacturing activities in outer space from Federal taxes and tariffs. The benefits will phase out gradually starting from 2014. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts space launch and manufacturing activities in outer space from Federal taxes and tariffs. A rule applies to benefits under subsection (c). A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for part III of subchapter B of chapter 1 of the Code. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" exempts space-related income from Federal taxes and tariffs. A new section is added for a credit for the purchase of qualified space company stock, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2005. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" introduces a credit for purchasing qualified stock in a domestic C corporation that is a qualified space company, with certain revenue criteria. The "Zero Gravity, Zero Tax Act of 2005" offers a credit for buying qualified stock in a domestic C corporation that is a qualified space company, meeting specific revenue requirements. Qualified stock is defined as any stock in a domestic C corporation if the entity's gross receipts do not exceed $100,000,000, and more than 70 percent of such receipts come from space-based business. Space-based business refers to a business with substantially space-related income. Aggregation rules similar to section 1202(d)(3) apply. Qualified stock in a domestic C corporation can be acquired by a taxpayer if the corporation is a qualified space company and the stock is obtained at its original issue in exchange for money, property, or as compensation for services provided. During the taxpayer's holding period for qualified stock in a C corporation, the corporation must meet active business requirements similar to those of section 1202(e) for a space-based business and be a C corporation. During the 10-year period after purchasing qualified stock, if the issuer no longer qualifies as a space company, the tax for that year will increase by the total decrease in credits under section 38. The section applies to stock acquired before December 31, 2013. It amends the definition of current year business credit and includes a space company investment credit. Conforming amendments are made to section 196 of the Code. The section amends the definition of current year business credit to include a space company investment credit. It also makes conforming amendments to section 196 of the Code. Sec. 45J introduces the Space Company Investment Credit, effective for costs incurred after December 31, 2005. Additionally, Sec. 1203 provides an exclusion for gains from the sale or exchange of stock of qualified space corporations. The provision excludes gain on the sale or exchange of stock of a qualified space corporation, defined as a domestic C corporation providing products or services in outer space. The provision excludes gain on the sale or exchange of stock of a qualified space corporation, defined as a domestic C corporation providing products or services in outer space. At least 90 percent of the expenses of such corporation must be attributable to the active conduct of a trade or business described in the provision. The provision excludes gains from selling or exchanging stock of qualified space corporations. Effective starting from taxable years after December 31, 2005.
